div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hedeirab. Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah at call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Official Residences.
div.p: Six large houses are being built at Khartoum by the Government for officials.

div.head: Al Azhar.
div.p: Sheikh Hassona El Nawawi is to be appointed chancellor of Al Azhar Univerity on the 1st prox.

div.head: Tour Eiffel Music Hall.
div.p: A special performance is to be given this evening for the benefit of Mle Morlaye, the Parisian "star."

div.head: Scorpions in the Sudan.
div.p: During 1906 no less than 151 persons were bitten by scorpions at Omdurman, nine of whom succombed.

div.head: All Dinar's Emissaries.
div.p: Two of Sultan Ali Dinar's emissaries are now in Khartoum and Omdurman, where they are shopping for their master.

div.head: Sudden Death.
div.p: A native of Alexandria dropped down deada yesterday while on his way to the mosque. Death was due to heart failure.

div.head: Khartoum Agricultural Show.
div.p: The Khartoum Annual Agricultural and Industrial Show for 1907 will be held in the Zoological Gardens on Friday February 22.

div.head: Egyptian University.
div.p: According to "Al Lews," the Khedive has selected his uncle, Prince Ahmed Fuad Pasha, as president of the committee of the Egyptian University.

div.head: Parricide Sentenced.
div.p: A Copt, named Rizk, who murdered his father for having embraced Islam, and also the latter's Moslem wife, has been sentenced by the Zagazig Criminal Court to penal servitude for life.

div.head: Big Provinvial Fire.
div.p: Our Damanhour Correspondent telegraphs that a big fire broke out yesterday at Tod and five houses were burnt down. Fortunately no one was injured. The amount of damage done has not yet been estimated.

div.head: Egyptian Directory.
div.p: The twenty first edition of Mr. Stegano G. Poffandi's Egyptian Directory is now ready. That useful annual publication is as up-to-date as ever, and fully maintains the high standard of efficiency for which it is so renowned.

div.head: Hard Labour for Omdeh.
div.p: Deshna Court has sentenced Tewfik Eff. Mihrar, omdeh of El THuseh, to one year's imprisonment with hard labour and a fine of L.E. 50 for drawing a forged bill for L.E. 600 on Abdelkarim, a resident of the same village; and sentenced three other natives implicated in the forgery each to six months' imprisonment with hard labour.

div.head: Crocodiles and Vultures.
div.p: The Cairo Golf Club has its course laid out on the island of Ghezireh, just across the Nile From several points, says a write in "Golfing Illustrated," anything of a drive will almost send a ball into the Nile ( where one may have to dispute its ownership with a crocodile), while at others it is liable to be swooped down upon by a vulture under the impression that it is a new kind of egg!!

div.head: Alexandria Water Supply.
div.p: We have reveived some complaints about the carbolic acid taste at present found in the drinking water at Alexandria. This slight taste in the filtered water, we understand, is of a perfectly harmless nature, and is caused by the clearing out of Kom el-Dik reservoir on Sunday, when the inside received a cost of composition which is perfectly wholesome, and is the same as that applied to new pipes, which sometimes cause a similar taste to appear. The taste has now almost disapppeared.

div.head: Hotel Semiramis.
div.p: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Bucher, of the Bucher-Durer Hotel Company of Lucerne, arrived at Alexandria by the Ncruh German Lloyd Hoherzollern, and have proceeded to Cairo to attend the opening ceremony of the Hotel Semiramis. The inauguration of this magnificent hotel will shortly take place. The hotel will be one of the most luxurious establishments of the kind in the world, and owing to its beautiful position on the banks of the Nile is ure to become one of the most fashionable hotels in Cairo.

div.head: KOURBAN BEYRAM.
div.p: KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION.

Cairo presented a particularly animated appearance this morning on the occasion of the great Khedivial reception of Kourban Beyram.. Numbers of officials from all parts of Egypt have arrived in the Capital in order to pay their respects to his Highness, and all this morning the streets leading to Abdeen Palace were filled with crowds of magnificently caparisoned personages of all degrees of rank.

The Kourban Beyram prayers were attended by the Khedive at Koubbeh mosque and a salvo of twenty one guns heralded his Highness's departure from the Mosque. Shortly before 8 o'clock the Khedive drove up to Abdeen, and the reception began a quarter of an hour afterwards with the arrival of the ulems. The reception continued throughout the mroning. The large attendance at this morning's reception was an eloquent testimony to his Highness's popularity. The Khedive, who looked in the best of health, received all-comers with his usual graciousness.

The Khedivah also held a reception this morning at Abdeen Palace from 9 to 11 30 o'clock, which was numerously attended by the Princesses of the Khedivial family and native ladies. Her Highness will also hold a reception from 3 to 4 30 o'clock this afternoon for the ladies of the Diplomatic Corps and other European ladies.
All the Ministires and Government offices at Cairo will be closed to day and throughout the Kourban Beyram holidays.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL TRAFFIC STOPPED.
div.p: Suez, Wednesday.

The S.S. Eosom, which was ashore in the Cnanal, was inflicted, and traffic was free again yesterday morning after a stoppage of about 20 hours. While the Epsom was ashore, a tug, having in tow a barge laden with stones, attempted to pass her, and owing to the strong S.W. wind the barge struck the steamer's canal rudder and sank, fortunately on the side of the canal. To-day traffic was again stopped for the operations to lift the sunken craft, but was clear again about 1 p.m.

div.head: RAISULI AND EGYPT.
div.p: In the high Moorish quarters at Tangier it is stated that the Sulatan has been advised to issue a Firman pardoning Raisuli, and the decree is expected to arrive there shortly. Raisuli will then be required to live either at Fez, in Egypt, or in Algeria.
It is, however doubtful whether Raisuili will accept such a settlement and surrender, unless his safety is guaranteed by two European Powers.

div.head: A TERRIBLE CATASTROPHE.
div.p: This morning's telegrams announce that the latest victim of the earthquake epidemic, which is now so much in evidence, is the island of Simalou or Varkens Eilard. It is an island of the Dutch East Indies, off the west coast of Sumatra. Simalou is, or was 2,100 square kilometers in extent and contained 10,000 inhabitants, Malays and Achinese. The island was renowned for its magnificent vegetation.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive has been graciously pleased to confer decorations on some members of the crew of his yacht Mahroussa. He has conferred the 4th class of the Order of the Medjidieh on Mr. David Hamilton, engineer, and the 5th class of the same order on Hefiz Effendi, officer of the Guard, Aly Demir and Ahmed Ryad, 1st lieutenants.

div.head: FROM NIGER TO NILE.
div.p: Lieut. Boyd Alexander the sole English survivor of the Gosling Alexander Expedition, which left Forcados on the Niger nearly thhree years ago, and who, in a steel boat, has completed the journey by water from the Ni to the Nile with the exception of shout fifteen days overland, passed thorugh Khartoum a few days ago on his way to England. The course of his journey lay across Luuke Chad and then S.E. thorugh the French Congo, the Free State, then N.E. through the Lado Enclave into the Bahr el Ghizeal until Shambe was reached.

This notable achievement which was commenced with forty two West Cost negroes, of whom fifteen are now remaining will contribute valuable information and throw much light on the exploration of those parts.

On the edge of the Congo Forest Lieut. Alexander succeeded in shooting an okapi, the animal that has been the subject of much curiousity and was in possession of its skin. Among numerous other specimens of different animals a young chimpanzee excited the most notice.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN PLOT.
div.p: WHO REVEALED ITS EXISTENCE

We are informed that the person who discovered the plot of the three Russian revolutionaires to blow up a steamer in Alexandria harbour, was a member of the secret police, David Markovitch by name, a Russian Jew, who has been for many years in Egypt. He was formely employed as a cigarette-maker by the "Khedive" Cigarette Company. Afterwards he entered the service of the Egyptian Hafis, and from his knowledge of Russian was of great use in watching the movements of Russian arrivals. It was he who, according to the Russian Jews, informed the Russian Consulate of the alleged plot. Markovitch was married twice and has a family resident in Moharrem Bey. Fearing reprisals, he has fled to Port Said. It is said that he came orginally from Odess, but for many years he had lived at Alexandria, where he was known to have anarchistic tendencies.

A meeting of Socialists was held at the Nouveates Theatre Cairo, yesterday on behalf of the three Russian prisoners. Vigorous resolutions were passed, and a demand for British intervention on behalf of the accused was, we understand, sent to the British Agency. We hear that Lord Cromer has since replied to this numerous other petitions that have reached him, but the tenour of the replies has not been publisehd.
In Cairo all is quiet at present, but there is an uneasy feeling that we have not seen the last of the manifestations.

div.head: A MEMORIAL.
div.p: The following is the substance of a memorial presented yesterday morning by Maltres Rossi and Chalom, spokesman of the manifestations, to SIr Malcolm Mellwraith and addresed to the Minister of Justice, Ibrahim Fuad Fasha, relative to the case of the three Russians. Acopy was also sent to the Khedive. The delegates afterwards called on Lord Cromer who promised to examine their petition. It is stated however, that his Lordship gave the delegates to understand that the Egyptian Government does not share their views.

After briefly recapitulating the recent events, the memorial reads:-"Extra-territoriality in the lands of the Capitulations does not extent to political crimes. If the Russo Turkish Treaty of 1774, which has here to be specially considered, does not contian the distinctions made in favour of such crimes, that was only afterwards introduced by the progess of the science of international law; it has enver the less experienced, in practice, at a later period an essential modification inspired by new principles that motived the memorable fefussal of Turkey in 1849 to extradite to Russia and Austria Russian and Hungarian refugees. If, therefore, the Egyptain Government is bound by no treaty to deliver up a person accused of a political crime, such extradition would constitute a free act of soverignty which it could carry out only after it had qualified the crime alleged."

The delegates therefore call for a judicial enquiry to determine the existence and nature of the act attributed to the three Russians. Moreover, according to the memorial, the Russo-Turkish Treaty of July 21, 1774 leaves of another the choice of their immediate delivery or expelling the,. The subscribers to this petition therefore pray the Egyptian Government to decide upon the expulsion of the Russians to appease the public conscience.

div.head: EGYPT AND RUSSIA
div.p: The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Boutros Pasha Ghali, paid an official visit yesterday to M. Smyrnoff the Russian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General, in order to formally aplogize on behalf of the Egyptian Government for the regrettable incidents which have recently occurred at Alexandria and Cairo.
Since Tuesday the Russian Diplomatic Agency and Consulate have been guarded by numerous mounted and foot police.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN. DEATH OF PROPHETS DESCENDANT.
div.p: Suakin, January 14.

Sheriffs Zenah bint Soy Samuel Murghani, wife of Sayid Guafer el Murghani, died here on the 11th inst, a few days after giving birth to a child. Both being descendants of the Prophet Mohamed, the Sayed did not think it right to allow a doctor to see his wife even while he knew that she was dying. Suakin is now in mourning for 14 days and the population will not feast during the coming Kourban Beyram.

div.head: THE SHRAGER BANKRUPTCY.
div.p: Upon the hearing of an application for discharge yesterday week by Mr. Cecili Shrager, a partner in the firm of Messrs. Shrager Brothers, formely trading as merchants in London, also at Calcutta, Alexandria, Singapore, Colombo, and elsewhere, it appeared from the trustee's report that the total liabilities of which he had been notified would amount to 153,252 that the assets had realised or would realise 5,533,12s., and that a dividend of not more than 2s in the pound would be paid to the creditors. The failure occurred in November, 1905 and was attributed to shortage in the jute crop and to the withdraw. The discharge was suspended for three years from June 13 last, when the applicant's examination was concluded.

div.head: K.S.C. SECOND WINTER MEETING
div.p: Unfortunately a cold biting wind prevented many people from attending the first day of this meething y sterlay. The weather was much more typical of England than Egypt, and it is to be hoped that we shall have a change soon. The attendance was dissappointing, but those who came were rewarded with some good racing. Once race especially, the Century Stakes, was worth going a long way to see; it is the best race we have seen this year, and Shour proves himself on this form about the best horse in Egypt, giving over a stonoe and a beating to Abou Nadara, and carrying same wights and defeating Roi de l'Air,- a splendid performance. Tridall had a nsaty fall in the Grand National Steeplechase but we believe his injuries are not serious Milk Punch, who is generally a very safe jumper clean overjumped himself. The course was in excellent condition. The new jockey standd was a useful, but at present not ornamental improvement. The Pari-Mutual did big business, about 1,8000 changing hands.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE. INCREEASE OF CAPITAL CONFIRMED.
div.p: At an extraordinary general meeting of the Khedivial Mail Steamship and Graving Dock Company Limited, held last week at Winchester House, London E.C., the resolution to increase the capital, passed on December 31, was confirmed.

div.head: NEW STEAMSHIP COMPANY.
div.p: A number of Greek capitalists are elaboratiing a scheme for the formation of a new line of steamers between Alexandria and the Pireaus, Salonica, Prieste Jaffa, and other posts in the Mediterranean.

div.head: MERCHANT SEAMEN'S HOME.
div.p: The annual New Year's treat given by the ladies of Ramleh to the seamen in port took place at the Home on Tuesday evening, when about 170 men sat down to a substantial report consisting of turkey, ham, joints, tea, and cakes, each man being presented with a packet of tobacco and a New Year's card given by Mrs. Moss. The arrangements were undertaken this year by Mrs. Sidney H. Carver, in succession to Mrs. Moss, who had on many past occassions so successfully organised there entertainments. The decorations were carried out by the manager, Captain Dingle, and his assistants, and the large hall presented a very festive appearance, festooned with flags lent by ships in the harbour, and adorned with greenery supplied by Mrs. Crafton, a small bouquet being laid at the side of each place on the tables. After the tables had been cleared the men were readmitted to a concert, organised by Mr. H. E. C. Moss, in which the following a lies and gentlemen took part: Messes Carver, Hewa'. and Pringle; Messrs. D. Allen, Clarke, De Rougemont, M. Moss, and F. Moss; Mrs. Crafton, Mrs. De Rougemont, Mrs. Pringle, and Miss Carver as accompanists on the pianoforte; the chair being taken by the Rev. A. H. Ellaby. Among the guests we noticed many Scandinavian from the timber vessels in port, and during the evening the audience was very considerably augmented by late arrivals. The usual votes of thanks were given, with cheers for Mrs. Carver, the ladies of Ramleh, and the chairman and for Mrs. Moss, who held in special remembrance, and the singing of the National Anthem concluded a most enjoyable evening.

The following ladies contributed to the ten Gifts in kind were received from: meadames M. Atkin, J. Atkin, Lang Anderson, Alderson. A. Alderson, D. Allen, Andrews, Birch, Birley, Bell, Crafton, Chataway, P.W. Carver, S.H. Carver Clarkson, F.Hasselden Hewat, Keiham, Mos, Molesworth, Prake Paull Ruffles, Satow, Swinglehurat, Strickland, and Williams Gifts in money were received from the following: Meadames Adamson, Borchgrevink, Brown, Crafton, Hasselden, Macpherson Grant, Peel Parkinson, Perc val, Princle, Richmond, Scott, and Van Horn, and Miss Manly.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: Owing to the very bad weather experienced during the past few days the Russian S.S. Tehbatchoff has been delayed and will not arrive tomorrow.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Duke George of Leuchentenberg which has been staying at Nice, is leaving shortly for a tour in Egypt.
Baron von Fleisch of Vienna, arrived at Shepheards's Hotel yesteday. The you officer will remain several days in Cairo at the Khedive's great.
Major-General R.S. Baden-Powell, C.R., Inspector-General of Cavalry, leaves for Egypt by the P. and O steamer Arabia, sailing from London tomorrow.
Sir Evre and Lady Coote have arrived in Egypt, where they inted to remain until after Easter.

The passenger list of the P. & O SS Macedonia included Lord and Lady Vivian, Sir R. Ruddolph, Sir Chas, and Lady Cayzer. Sir Auckland Colvin, Sir Eyre and Lady Coote, and the Duke of Pramada. The aprty went on immediately to Cairo from Port Said.
Col. Count Gerichen has returned to St. Jame's Palace on giving up his appointment as Military Attache at Washington.

Sir Ernet Cassel is arriving in Egypt in a few days' time, accompanied by Mr. and Mrs. Wilford Ashley for his annual visit/ Sir Benjamin Baker will accompany Sir Ernest. Sir Ernest Cassel's interests in Egypt now total up to a huge sum, and his optimism in the future of the country is almost unbounded. It will be remembered that he found most of the money for the construction of the great barrage at Assouan. Stepping in when the French were hesitating it was he who financed the National Bank of Egypt, and a syndicate of his creation invested a few years ago. no less than five millions in Egyptian land. He is interested in some dozens of other enterprises in the country of Old Nile.

Professor Shwa'nfurth, who is staying at the Continental Hotel, is one of the best known German explorers. and recently celebrated his 70th birthday. During his college days he showed a great interest in exploring, biology, and designing, and botany and paleontology were his favorite studies. After several journeys through Austria-Russia. and Sardinia, he came to Alexandria and studied the flora of the Nile delta and in 1866 he visited Khartoum. Three years later he went to the Congo and in 1870 he visited the cannibal colony of Niam-Niam.

In Monbutti Prof. Schwinfurth discovered a Lillipurain race with an average adult height of 1w 5cw, and also the river Ulla fluss, which he believed to have its souics in Lake Chad. On his return his valuable collection and books were destroyed by fire, but he was able to repeat the designs from memory. In 1873 he went on a botanical expedition to the Lyhien desert, and in 1884 he was called by Khedive Ismail to Circe, where he founded the Geographical Society.

Youssef Bey Saddik a notable of Cairo gave a banquet in honour of Mr. J. Robertson, M.P., on Tuesday last, which was attended by a number of well-known natives Mr. Robertson visited the Cairo prisons yesterday.

The marriage took place at Paisley last week of Mr. Peroy Illingworth M.P. for the Shipley Division of York hire who has acted as private secretary to Mr. Birrell the Education Minister, and Miss May Coats, of Paisley. The honeymoon will be spent in Egypt.

The engagement is announced of Mr. F. Chaker, sub-manager for Egypt of the International Sleeping Cairo Company, to Mile Elive Lekegian, the charming daughter of Mr. Lekegian, the well-known holographic artist of Cairo.

The services of Mr. Areundais laie engineer to the Alexandria Municipality have been engaged by the Sudan Land Company. He has been visiting Khartoum in order to report on some estates there and is due back in a week's time.

The following visitors arrived at the Luxor Winter Palace, Luxor, between the 20th and 22nd inst: Prince Djewil Toussoun and suite, Cairo; Mwe Kundineco, Alexandria; M., Mme and mlle Boittre, Brussels; Mr.. Mrs and Misa Smyh, London; Mr. C. Couri, Athens; Prof. Andresdes Athens; Elisa Pey Awail; Prof. Andreades. Athens; Ehias Fey Awail, Cairo; Mr and Mrs William Felton Pea, Alexandria; Mr. W. Williamtono, Cairo; Mr. F. Spathis, Cairo: Mr. Charles Royle, Cairo.

div.head: FREAKS OF WEATHER. NICE COLDER THAN ICELAND PHENOMENAL CLIMATIC CONDITIONS

div.p: The cold is spreading westward and is becoming more instense in Great Britain owing to a fierce east wind. The temperature in Belgium is at zero (Fahrenheit) 13 degrees below zero in Berlin, and 32 below zero in Austria-Hungary, where many deaths have occurred. Continental railway services are disorganised. The popes in the engines are freezing and splitting. The Danube and Odessa harbour are frozen. The barometer fromo Russia to Great Britain is the highest on record. Iceland at present is 30 degrees warmer than Nice. (Reuter)
Trains have been snowed up several feet deep between here and Naples. (Reuter)
Navigation on the Bosphorous and Euxine has been suspended. (Reuter)

div.head: EARTHQUAKE IN EAST INDIES. ISLAND ALMOST DISAPPEARS.

div.p: (Official). The Island of Simalu was visited by an earthquake on the 11th instant, and has since almost disappeared, 1,500 persons have been killed. Violent earthquake shocks are occurring daily. The Governor of the Dutch East Indies has sailed for Simalu with medical aid. (Reuter)

The prolonged absence of a British warship from Kingston has attracted attention to the effects of the distribtuion of the Navy, and its disadvantages are revealed. It has been strongly criticized in England and the Colonies. It transpires that the whole of the North America Squadron is at present in British ports at home, except the Isis, which is at Gibraltar, and the Indefatigable. The Colonial Office has received despatches from Sir James Swettenham which will not be published. They practically confirm the correspondence which was said to have taken place. (Reuter)
The Mehalla is resuming operations against Beninossaouer, where Raisuli has taken refuge. (Havas)
M. Klobukowski has been promoted to the first class of his rank. (Havas)
The Chamber has passed the bill increasing the emeluments of the clergy. (Havas)

The Chancellor has received a visit from Herr Albert Gohat, General Secretary of the Inter-Parliamentary Union. The next general Congress of the Union will take place in Berlin. The Chancellor promised his full sympathy with the work in a letter addressed to Herr Eickhoff, President of the German party of the Union. (Reuter)

The "Norddeutsche Allgemeine Zuitung" publishes the text of the treaty between Germany and Denmark settling the question with regard to the children of Danish subjects in German territory. By this treaty this difficult question which has often been discussed is definitely settled. (Reuter)

div.head: A MUSIC HALL STRIKE. LONDON HALLS CLOSED.

div.p: A strike of music-hall artistes and employes has taken place. This is due to the question of extra pay for matinees. Six balls including the Tivoli, were closed yesterday evening. Eight others have been holding makeshift performances. Leading artistes are identified with the movement. (Reuter)

div.head: THE "EGYPTIAN STANDARD." EXTRAORDINARY STORY.
div.p: No newspaper has ever been launced in Egypt, about which there has been so much discussion as the "Egyptian Standard." Even in America the Press is full of the strangrest tales about the incubation of the organ of Mustapha Pacha Kamel. As a specimen o the world-wide interest taken in the "Patriots" latest journalistic venture we may cite the following from a Roumanian correspondent of the "New York American." The news that the King of the Belgians is concerned in the paper will add a new interest to our contemporary, when it does appear. It will be remembered that the Pasha paid some visits to Brussels in the summer. Our contemporary's Brails correspondent writes:-

"With reference to your disclosures about King Leopold's corruptive crusade in the Unites States, of which I have received small cable extracts, I beg to infrom you of an analgous propaganda by King Leopold in Egypt against the British cooperation.

"A certain Egyptian Prince. Mustafa Kamel Pasha, apparently made a donation of 500,000 francs ($100,000) to launch in Cairo an anti English paper in French and English, and it appears that the real donor is in reality King Leopold, while Mustafa Kamel Pasha is only the straw man.

"If the United States Government will not take prompt and vigorous action against King Leopold, I should not be surprised that very soon as native anti-American proganda shall be on foot in the Phillipines."

div.head: MONTGAGES IN EGYPT. AN INTERESTING REPORT
div.p: We have received comparatively recently an extract from the report of the Belgian Consulate dealing with the various facts and phases connected with the past and present state of mortgages and mortgage debts in this country (Recueil Consulaire de Belgiqae. Annie 1906, Tome 136).

The part treating of the mortgage debt has been compiled by Dr. Alfred Bid, and it is obvious that in its compilation the author has taken infinite pains in collecting the various figures and statistics and in arranging them in a clear and concise manner, with the result that notwithstanding the somewhat severely statistical appearance ot the work the brochure must prove of the greatest interest to all who feel a real concern in the welfare and prosperity of the country. As the author explains in his introduction, the collection of the figures and statistics showing the total amount of the mortgage debt of the country at any given moment is not so simple a matter as might be supposed. To ths average individual it would epje*r a i task of no great difficulty. All mortgages, he ' will argue, are registered compulsorily at one of the three greffaa at Cairo, Alexandria, and Mansonrah, and the official publication ot jibe** in »he annual report of the Ministry ot Jastioe should give all the reqnired information. But nnfortnnately in the annual report thsre is merely made known the number of entries in the registers and no aooonot is taken of mortgages that are extiogni«hed, of sums annually amortised, or even of the actual area of the property mortgaged.

Dr. Eid therefore has made personal enquiries, and in giving us his results he divides his work into the four parts into which it naturally falls: 1. The fixing of the amount of mortgage debt; 2. A brief account of its past and present state and an analysis of the factors that have led to its increase; 3. Its bearing on the economic situation and on the future of Egypt; 4. His conclusions after a brief comparison with the principal countries in Europe.

And we for our part cannot do better than give a brief resume of the results of his labour and research. In the first place it becomes necessary to separate and keep separate the amount of the mortgage debt properly so called from the amounts remaining owing on land sold on the instalment system (ventes a terme) where the vendor retains a lien on the land until fully paid. And further, the mortgage debt properly so called must be subdivided into two classes, (1) that contracted with banks and mortgage companies or institutions de credit foncier and (2) that contracted with private individuals or private companies: for in the former subdivision the publication of annual balance-sheets and accoutns makes it simple to trace the mortgage operations, wheareas in the latter they remain largely a matter of conjecture or at best approximation. Three public banks and mortgage companies, of each of which Dr. Eid gives us a brief history amount in his estimation to five namely, Le Credit Foncier Egyptien, the Land and Mortgage Companyt of Egypt, la Caisse Hypothecaire d'Egypte the Land Bank, and last but by no means least, the Agricultural Bank of Egypt. Of these, the Credit Foncier is the oldest and most important, having a capital of L.E. 7,715,000 of which one-half is now called up, and a debenture capital of L.E. 15,189,685. Up to the 1st January, 1906, it had advancced on loan L.E. 11,139,913 of which sum over halt at that date had been paid off, and it was to the Credit Foncier Egyptien that the Daira Sanieh granted the right to collect the moneys due on the centes a terme of its properties amounting in all to L.E. 8,000,000. The next in age is the Land Bank of Egypt was only started in 1905, but its total resources at the 31st December last reached the figure of nearly L.E. 2,000,000. Lastly, the Agricultural Bank of Egypt deserves and obtains a special mention, being as it is a quasi-official undertaking sided by a guarantee of a 3% dividend and by the concession of other privilege from the Government. Founded in 1902 it has now a capital in shares anda debentrues of over L.E. 6,00,000. This is employed in loans of amounts varying from L.E. 1- to L.E. 500 to the small agriculturist on the usual mortgage terms or in advances varying from P.T. 50 to L.E. 20 on the guraantee of his crop. WIth the introduction of this institution a heavy blow was dealt at the excessive usury practised up till 1902 by the village money lenders whose wealth increased in proportion as that of the fellaheen decreased: for the poorer and more straightened the position of the fellah the higher the rate on the money which he was forced by stress of circumstances to borrow from these notorious Shylocks.

Disregarding the balance sheet for 1903, saying that it included seven months of 1902 and counted in loans transferred from the parent stem, the National Bank of Egypt, in the year 1904, roughly speaking, 50,000 loans were granted, amounting to nearlyt L.E. 2,000,000 making the averagew amount of a loan L.E. 40, and in 19095 58,432 loans were granted at an average of L.E. 42 per loand amounting to L.E. 2,459,987, as against 1991 loans, at an average amount of L.E. 3,690 amounting to L.E. 7,421,488, advanced by the other four "etablissements de credit foncier". So a very cursory examination of these figures will show the difference in the class of clients seeking the aid fo the Agricultural Bank and of those requesting advances from the other four institutions.

A table of statistics that Dr. Eid gives us here shows the increase of the mortgage debt of the country since 1901 and proves that dsince that date, withoiut taking the loans of the Agricultural Bank into consideration, the mortgages have increased from about L.E. 5,000,000 in amount to over L.E. 20,000,000 and from 2,840 in number to 5,219 that is to say, have doubled in number and quadrupled in amount.

At first the E.A. looked like winning, Capt. Collum especially distinguishing himself, and for the Gunners Capt. Napier did most work and made some very fine runs.

The E.A. scored first goal in the 1st chucker, from a brilliant run by Capt. Collum; and it was not until the 3rd chuckker that the Gunners equalized. The E.A., however came again, brining the score to 2 to 1.
In the 4th chuckker the Gunners certainly outplayed their opponents. Capt. Napier, seeming to hav ve matters his won way, scored 2 goals in quick successsion, thus winning the match for his side.

div.head: THE ANNALS OF ISLAM.
div.p: Towards the close of the sixth century Western Asia and the greater part of Europe were divided between Rome and Persia. The Roman Empire, seated at Byzantium had recently undergone the great revival of the earlier years of Justinian's reign, followed by the equally important but as yet unnoticed decadence that resulted from the Emperor's efforts to recapture the Western portions of his dominions, whereby he brought the rich Eastern provinces to the verge of ruin. The Persian Empier, splendid as it still as to the outward eyes had been rocked to its foundations by the Mazlakite schism, and had been obliged to stretch its military resources to the utmost in the effort to guard its northern frontiers against the white Hans. Morever, Greeks and Persians alike were weakened by the disastours internecine wars which they waged ceaselessly upon each other. Justinian died in 565 surviving by a few months only the most famous of his generals, Belissarius; Narses, the other distinguisehd military leader of the reign, died in 567; Chosroe Nushirwan, the last great figure in the annals of the Sassanian Emperors of Persia in 579. It was as though Destiny had cleared the decks of the world for action, knowing that the time was ripe, for the Prophet of Islam was born at Meccain in the year 470 Tradition has been busy with the signs and portents that accompanied his birth and surrounded his early years, but of historic facts none have been preserved, not even his true name, that of Mohamed being probably a cognomen. We know only that he was an orpham, a member of the merchant tribe of Qurayah (though, indeed, critical examination shows the links in the chain of his lineage to be singularly untrustworthy), brought up in the house of his grandfater, and as little considered by the busy society of traders and pilgrims that surrounded himi as he would have been in Byzantiu or Ctesiphou, if the news of his existence could have reached those two capitals of civilisation. He died at the age of sixty-two having laid the foundations of a new Empire as wide embracing as either of those which he found, and more durable than either.

It is the story of this achievement, together with the history of the Mohamedan Empire for nine hundred years, until the overthrow of the Mameluke Sultans of Egypt by the Turks in 1517, that Prince Tesno has set himself to write,- a colossal task if it is to be accomplished with the same minute care that he has expanded upon the first volume. He permits no aspect of his subject-social, moral, political, or religious- to escape him; he intersperses his chronological record with critical notes which show great learning and sound judgment, and with long digressions in which he weighs cause and result and sums up the general bearing of the events which he relates. His toil is lightened by the fact that he can draw upon the labours of famous Orientalists who have, in the past fifty years, covered the ground with chich he now deals, but he does not spare himself the toruble of examining anew the texts upon which their work was founded, and he brings to the study of his authorities, both ancient and moderm, an acute criticism combined with the true historic sense. Such a book as this (the first volume racs to seven hundred and forty large quarto pages, and we are promised eleven volumes more) may not be read consecutively by a wide audience; but the conclusions at which the author arrives will help to form the verdict of students upon one of the most astonishing phenomena in the world's history, the birth and power of Islam. It is a phenomenon which enters largely into our own problems of governmentm and therefore the successive volumes of Prince Tesno's book will be of great interest to us. By throwing the light of the past upon the difficulties of the present he may clear the way to the solution of many doubtful points, and lay bare the origin and strength of many a force with which we still have to contend.

The figure of Mohamed is like a touchstone upon which to test the insight of historians. Few views are sufficiently comprehensive. If Mohamed did not find a martyr's end, it was not because the spirit to meet such a solution was lacking. There can be no doubt of his sincerity during the early years of his mission; the chapters of the Koran revealed at Mecca before the Flight are good and sufficeinet evidence. WIth an ardent eloquence and an admirable simplicity, he preached during these years of obscurity and struggle the religion of the one true God. He wa not occupied with the posistion of His rasul, His prophet; it was a role that it had not occurred to him to assume. Nor was he concerned with kingdoms of this world; conquest by arms was an idea that had not entered his mind. He was but the mouthpiece of the Divine Spirit, calling upon his own tribe, and upon any other Arab tribe whom he could induce to lilstem to relinquish the worship of stocks and stones and lift their eyes to that which was eternal. From what source Mohamed drew his conception of divine unity is a question of the deepest signifigance Jews and Christians were both to be found at Mecca; from them, and particularly from the Jews he must have learnt. He grasped the main idea of both faiths, monotheism and that was enough. Perhaps, as Prince Teano points out, if the Qurayeh had listened to him he would have been content to go no further; it was their obstinate refusal that forceed him into the wider field, and turned Islam into a world-religion. Hiss life was not in danger at Mecca; according to Arab custom, he was under the protection of powerful members of his own family, and his murder would have brought the perils of blood-feud about the ears of those who had laid hands on him. But he and his small band of followers were exposed to constant annoyance, and the faith made no progess. It was at this moment that the intolerable confusion that reigned at Median induced the inhabitatnts of that city to look round for some means of restoring order. During their pilgrimage to the shrine at Mecca they heard Mohamed's preaching, they observed the organisation and the spirit of obedience that ruled among his converts, they elected him as a political leader, and adopted in large numbers his religion.

Prince Teano gives us in this volume the history of the first six years at Medina. We see Mohamed, by force of circumstance changed into a statesman a lawgiver a leader of armies courting favour coursting success by every means known to statecraft, his personal authority growing day by day, and with it his estimation of himself, until we find him no longer preaching the religion of God, but that of Mohamed, the Propjhet of God, He met with opposition in plenty,- from the rich Jewish colony, whom he tried at first to mollify, and then turned upon in a very passion of pitiless revenge; from the Quaryah who led strong and sometimes successful armies into the field against him. But there was no real union between the forces of his enemies. The Jews hated the Arabs, and the Arabs hated each other, as they do to this day, and one by one the Prophet triumphed over them all.

The Prophet's hold uupon the personal devotion of his followers never weakened, and wiser still to bear in mind Prince Teano's prfound reflection that it is easier to die a saint at the stake than upon a throne. "The figure of Mohamed," says he, "loses in beauty, but it gains in strength; all the process of evolution which his spirit traversed has a quite peculiar interest, for possibly no man before or after him had a life like his. He began his career when he had already reached the age of forty as an honest a sincere preacher, fightning in the name of a great truth, not for his own material interests, but for the moral interests of the society in which he lived. He died the absolute and supreme head of a theocratic Empire, founder of a militant religion which laid claim to the dominion of the world; both these results were direct products of his moral and intellectual vigour."

Mohamed, then, was much more than the prophet of a new creed; he was the creator of a social entity of which his countnryment had had no conception. He welded the Arab tribes into a nation,- a nation of warriors who subdued half Asia, a nation of rulers who founded capitals in Mesopotamia and in Spain where the torch of learning burnt through the darkness of the early Middle Ages. It may be that Prince Teano is right, when he says that to the Arabs the political aspect of Islam was more important than the religious, and that it was the subject-peoples, reft of all hope of wordly supremacy and by nature inclined to metaphysical speculationm who developed the doctrinal side of Mohamed's teaching. His empire, which he had first conceived as being one of the spirit, passed after his death through all the phases of mundane greatness and decline, and has ended as a powerful moral force, governing the thoughts and acts of men very different from one another in race but united by the bond of the faith. How strong that union is, and whether it could again be given the vital spark of common political purpose, are questions that present themselves continually, in these days of Pan-Islamism, for our practical consideration.

div.head: MR. ROBERTSON M.P.
div.p: Mr. Robertson's visit still continues to occupy the attention and fill the columns of our local contemporaries; to such extent, indeed that as the following controv ray shows, they are using him as the innocuous shuttlecock o a plemical battledore. Lorth as we are to join in the game, we cannot refrain from gently rebuking the rather too forcible language employed by "Al Minbar" in its retort to the "Mokattam." Says "Al Mokattam:" "We have been asked why we say nothing about Mr. Robertson while the other papers, and especially those of the Opposition, do not fail to record his least doings and sayings. Our reply is that Mr. Robertson's goings and comings do not concern us at all. THere are a number of English tourists in Egypt just now who are far more important than him, socially, scientifically, and politically; there are also others who have infinitely more influence in their own country and yet for all that we have never thought to record their words and acts. The fact of other newspapers concerning themselves there with does not necessarily imply that we are obliged to do the same. True, we visited and interviewed Mr. Robertson in London. It was to know his opinion on the Denishwai affairs. The Opposition papers had made such a lot of noise about his name, that we thought it our duty to report to our readers his own statements."

To this "Al Minbar" retorts: It is a lie; a pure invention. Mr. Robertson at first refused to be interviewed, and then to be led by a man of no importance in Egypt (e.g., Drz Fair Nimr, of the "Mokattam"); this man is niether Egyptian nor English; he is a salaried interloper. After the proposals he had made and the refuasal he received he has the audacity to declare that Mrs. Robertson does not worry him abit. To conclude, we inform this interloper that Mr. Robertson does not pretend to expel the English from Egypt, nor to upset the world, that the Egyptians who associate with him do not believe or hope so. We respect him because he sees that it is not to the interest of his own country to govern by fear and violence."

div.head: EGYPTIAN PEACE-MAKERS
div.p: As the ordered civilisation which it has been our privilege introduce into modern Eygpt is extended and more southwaeds "fax into the remote Sudan" it becomes more necessary that the forces which have been instrumental in planting that civilistaiton in those parts should be enlarged. Progress has been made by means of the Army; and the Army, now of the fine national standard that is led by British officers, is extending its operations into all those parts of the Sudan where the last of the insurgents have taken refuge, as did the Findari and Mahratta chiefs after the great campaigns of Marquees Hastings in India. The cost of maintaining peace is not excessive; but it grows heavier as the circle of operations enlarges; the Egyptian War Budget for 1907; as announced by the "Times" Cairo correspondent, shows an increase of nearly 130,000. It cannot be said that this is extravagant, when we consider the work that is done for it. The earliest frontier outposts were of little use since the garrison two years ago represented but one soldier for three hundred square miles of territory. Against Arab and Dervish raids, such puny defences could do nothing effectual, especially since the mountainous haunts of the plunderers were almost unknown to Europeans, and a system of terrorism was hung over the heads of the luckless wretches who might have been tempted to betray them. The Dongola and White Nile provinces are now at peace: in Eout-East Kordofan, however in the wild districts even more remote, and in the Babr-el Ghazal, there is still much to be done. But when it is remembered that ten years ago the battle of Omdun man was not yet fought, there will be few associations of slackeness levelled at the Egyptain Army. ("The Globe")

div.head: SAMOS.
div.p: The Samos Question is one that is likely sooner or later to attact European attention, and particularly Great Britain, thorugh whose good offices it was that in 1840 the island was granted its autonomy. Faction, however, the canker of Greek political life, has checked the progress of the isle, and more than once led to riot in which blooshed occurred.

Recently, as the result of the attack of the Soufouli party the Bey, Janko Effindi Bithyonos, tendered his resignation. He was succeeded by Prince Constantine Caratheodory, brother of the celbrate Ottoman statesman who signed the Treaty of Berlin; but clever diplomatist as he is there is no knowin gwhen his time for going may come. THus far the torubles of the isle have been strictly internecine, but a recnt affair in which Greeka and Turkish toops were killed has compellled the Porte, as the Suznair, to interfere in the Principality's affairs, much to the annoyance of the Samians. With a view to restoring and guaranteeing order the Porte has signified to the Constitutional Assembly its intentiono of appointing a Turkish military governor to Samos. To this the islanders have as a man objected and a strongly worded protest so we understand has been sent to Constantinople on the subject. It is probable that Great Britain may intervene, in the event of a revolt.

div.head: DR. WILLIAMS PINK PILLS.
div.p: " 'How pale and bloodless she looks' was the expression I often heard as I passed through the streets," said Mrs. Annie Preston, who when interviewed at 26, Wellington street, Stott Hill, Bradford, recalled the time of intense suffering that darkened her existence yet to day Mrs. Preston is well, happy and ective, and for this restoration she gives every credit to Dr. Williams' Pink Pills.
"As a girl,: she said, "I was always-pale and delicate, so muchh so that when in company I became quite ashamed of my deathly pallor
"But this was not my worst trouble. My eyes became sunken and glassy, my gums white, and my tongue discoloured. Then I lost all vitality and strength; my breath was short and painful.
Stabbing Pains of Indigestion

attacked me in the chest after every meal until eventually I dreaded the sight or smell of food even such simple diet as bread and butter produced a distressing fulness, followed by a lurking sensation.
"My head was racked with pains across my forehead, and my right grew dim; many times during the day I felt a reeling sensation overcome me.

'My whole body became weak and languid and the slightest exertion excited pain. My deep at night was broken, and in the morning I would rise feeling dead tired and unfit for anythin. Breakfast was always left untouched except perhaps a cup of tea.
'All interest in life disappeared, and anemia so ravaged my system that I really
Looked years older than I was.
My nerves became unstung, and my hands tumbled so violently that I could not hold a tea cup.
"If I went upstairs I was attacked by cruel palpitation of the heart and loss of breath, and felt so puffed out that I frequently collapsed and remained there until assistance came.
"So seriously did these symptoms develop that at last I was red iced to a skeleton, and inked like a girl in the last stages of commotion.

"It was only when I was verging on despair that my mother insisted tha*. I should try Dr. Williams Pink Pills. I began them, and after a time I could tell that slowly but surely a marvelous change was coming over me. When I had emptied ths third box I even began to take a little solid food, which I digested readily. Then I found my strength was being built up rapidly I regained my height my origin spirits and lost my haggard appearauoe. I continued to mend, and in two mouths felt
Quits Myself Again.

with my nerves so strong that I always felt well. Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People dispersed all traces of anemia with the terrible palpitations and feeling of utter exhaustion ; more than that they built up my health and strength until 1 became as hearty and active as you see me now."

In both sexes they have cured not only anemia but General Weakness, idigestion, Eczema, Rhenmaism, Sciatics, Neuralgia, St. Vitus' Dance, Paralysis; in ladies special ailments they are invaluable. div.head: LE REGLEMENT DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Nous sommes heureux de pouvoir donner a nos lecteurs que'ques extraits du projet de reglementation de la Bourse du Caire que le gouvernement etudie actuellement:
MODIFICATION AU CODE DE COMMERCE
Des Courtiers et des Bourses

Art. 77.-Aucune Bourse de Commerce ne peut etre ouverte sans l'antorisation du Governement. Il y aura dans chaque Bourse une Commision chargee de la direction et un ou plusieurs commissaires du Gouvernement pour veiller a l'observation des Reglements. Art 78.-Aucune operation ne sera valablement concise en Bourse qu'en conformite d'un Reglement sanctionne par un Decret Khedivial, rendu sur l'avis conforme de la Cour d'Appel Mixte d'Alexandrie.
REGLEMENTATION DE LA BOURSE
Composition et attributions de la Commission de la Bourse.

Art 1er.- La direction de la Bourse est confiee a une Commission composes de 12 a 16 membres, dont la moitie sera choisie parmi les ceurtiers, un quart parmi les Asseseurs Commerciaux et un quart parmi les banquiers. Les membres de cette Commission seront designes pour deux aus par le Ministre des Finances sur la presentation de deux listes dresses chaque annee, l'une par le College des Asseseurs Commerciaux, l'autre par les courtiers remain en Assembles Generale.

SOUSCRIPTION A 60,000 ACTIONS DE CAPITAL NOUVELLES

En verte des pouvoirs qui lui sont confe ete par l'article 8 des Statuts, le Conseil d'Administation par deliberations eu date des 26 Novembre, 21 Decembre 1906 et 16 Janvier 1907, a decide de porter le capital a:
30,000,000 de fracs
par l'emission de 60,000 actions de capital nouvellles et a detemine les conditions de cette augmentation de capital.
Ces actions numerotees de 60,001 a 120,000 seront smieses jouissance ler Janvier 1907.
E les auront les memes droits et avanta es les actions de capital existances.
DROIT DE SOUCRIPTION
1. SOUSCRIPTIONS PRIVILECIES ET IRREDUCTIBLES.
Tout prteur de DEUX ACTIONOS anciennes (capital on dividende) a le droit de souscrize une action de capital nouvelle.
2. SOUSCRIPTION EVENTUELLES ET REDUCTIBLES.

Les actions nouvelles. pour lequelles ete droit de prefference n'aura pas ete exerce, serout repartissentre les actionnaires anciencs qui les reclamerout par une souscription speciale eventuelle et reductible.
Ces actions eront reparties au prorats des anciene titres posseddee par les souscripteurs sans que la limite indulquee par eux dans leurs souscriptions reductibles puisse etre depasse.
PRIX DE LA SOUSCRIPTION
Le prix de la souscription est fixe a 251 fran par titre, payables de la maniere suivants:
Frs. 63,50 en souscrivant

Les souscriptions en retard d'effectuer ce dernier versement serout possibles d'un interest de 5% l'an, a partir de la date de sou exigibilite, nonobatant les autres atipulations le l'article 9 des statuts.

Les titulaires ou portuers des actions anciennes (capital ou dividende) pourroont user de leur dernit de preference en taissant estampiller leurs titres du samedi 26 Janvier au samedi 9 Fevrier inclus aux banques ciapres designees"

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
